awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Time-of-Fight Secondary Ion Mass Spectrometer
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Description:
This Major Research Instrumentation award provides support for the acquisition of a state-of-the-art instrument for time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectrometry (ToF-SIMS). This is a critical technique needed to understand surface composition and reactivity across chemistry, materials science, environmental science, chemical engineering, conservation science, and physics. The ToF-SIMS method is an extremely sensitive surface analytical technique that uses a pulsed ion beam to remove the outmost monolayers of the sample. The species that are removed from these atomic monolayers (secondary ions) are accelerated and their masses (or more precisely mass-to-charge ratios) are determined by the exact time at which they reach the detector (hence time-of-flight). In a broader sense, the acquisition of this instrument supports collaboration efforts among the different colleges at the University of Delaware, industrial companies in the state of Delaware, and the Winterthur Museum. The instrument is used by students in graduate and advanced undergraduate research, graduate courses, the Art Conservation Program, and students in several research experience for undergraduate programs at the University of Delaware, including research experience specifically designed for students with disabilities.

Technical Description:
In general, there are three ToF-SIMS operational modes: surface spectroscopy with better than 0.0001 amu resolution that enables molecular identification and isotopic content in the parts-per-million range; surface imaging with better than 100 nm spatial resolution, ~3000x smaller than the diameter of a human hair; and depth profiling - when combined with a second ablation beam (generally, ions of oxygen and cesium) to achieve vertical resolution of less than 1 nanometer. The acquired instrument satisfies all these criteria. These capabilities directly affect a large number of current and future research directions at the University of Delaware. The research areas include atomic-precision deposition and etching, nanotechnology and nanomaterials, efficient solar-cell design, heterogeneous, thermal, and electrocatalysis, cultural heritage investigations, research in microplastics and biomedical interfaces, and many other efforts. ToF-SIMS provides a powerful method with atomic precision, surface-sensitivity, high depth resolution, and imaging capabilities to answer critical questions and to define further research and discovery directions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This proposal was aiming at acquiring Time-of-Flight Secondary Ion Mass Spectrometer (ToF-SIMS) for the Surface Analysis Facility at the University of Delaware. Time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectrometry (ToF-SIMS) is a critical technique needed to understand surface composition and reactivity across chemistry, materials science, environmental science, chemical engineering, conservation science, and physics. TOF-SIMS is an extremely sensitive surface analytical technique that uses a pulsed ion beam to remove the outmost monolayers of the sample. The species that are removed from these atomic monolayers (secondary ions) are accelerated and their masses (or more precisely mass-to-charge ratios) are determined by the exact time at which they reach the detector (hence time-of-flight).

The obtained TOF.SIMS 5 instrument (IONTOF USA, Inc., Attached Figure) was acquired and set-up. In order to properly manage the instrument and the facility, the Director of this facility was hired. The instrument is now used on a regular basis by 17 research groups at the University of Delaware, 5 academic institutions outside the state, and 5 industrial companies. The research involves the famous Winterthur Museum, Garden, and Library complex located within a few miles of the university and also the University of Delaware’s Institute of Energy Conversion, the oldest solar research facility in the world and one of only two recognized as a Center of Excellence for Photovoltaic Research and Education by the U.S. Department of Energy.

This instrument has affected positively research in atomically-precise manufacturing, material design, composite materials, plant and soil science, catalysis, solar cells, polymers, and cultural heritage. It is an integral part of graduate and undergraduate education. From a pedagogical perspective, this instrument provides unique experience for graduate students and postdoctoral fellows. This experience is invaluable in future positions for this workforce. Of the recent hires, at least 4 utilize the instrument, at least two of the hires by the University pf Delaware in the current year expressed interest in utilizing this instrument of their research. The facility, and specifically this ToF-SIMS instrument, is now a permanent fixture on the tours by perspective graduate students.

 


Last Modified: 10/17/2024
Modified by: Andrew V Teplyakov

Image
  • Director of Surface Analysis Facility Dr. Xu Feng is training graduate research assistants on a newly setup TOF.SIMS 5 instrument
    n/a
    Public Domain
    Andrew V Teplyakov
    Graduate student training on ToF-SIMS
